[[Image:DogSledRace.jpg|thumb|Racing across the snow]] [[File:Dogsledatrest.jpg|thumb|Dogsled huskies at rest, Ottawa, Canada, 2011]]
A '''dog sled''' or '''dog sleigh'''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/dog-sleigh|title=Collins 2012 digital dictionary|accessdate=3 December 2014}}</ref> is a [[sled]] pulled by one or more [[sled dog]]s used to travel over [[ice]] and through [[snow]]. Numerous types of sleds are used, depending on their function. They can be used for [[dog sled racing]]. In [[Greenland]] the dogs pull in a fan shape in front of the sled opposed to other regions where to dogs pull side by side in pairs.
==History== Dog power has been used for hunting and travel for over a thousand years. As far back as the 10th century BCE these dogs have contributed to human culture.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tworiversak.com/sleddoghx1.htm |title=Early Sled Dog History |last1=Swan | first1=Thom |website=Swanny's Place |accessdate=17 October 2013}}</ref>
Assembling a dog sled team involves picking leader dogs, point dogs, swing dogs, and wheel dogs. The lead dog is crucial, so [[mushing|mushers]] take particular care of these dogs. Another important detail is to have powerful wheel dogs to pull the sled out from the snow. Point dogs (optional) are located behind the leader dogs, swing dogs between the point and wheel dogs, and team dogs are all other dogs in between the wheel and swing dogs and are selected for their endurance, strength, and speed as part of the team. In dog sledding, [[Siberian Huskies]] or [[Alaskan Malamutes]] are the main types of dogs that are used for recreational sledding because of their strength and speed and endurance as well as their ability to withstand the cold. However, [[Alaskan husky|Alaskan Huskies]] (a mix between Siberian Huskies and Alaskan Malamutes) are also a popular dog for sled dog racing, because of their endurance, good eating habits, speed, and dedication to running even when tired.{{citation needed|date=February 2017}}
Sometimes, for sprint races, mushers use short haired hounds that are faster than the average [[husky]]. These hounds are raised from a young age to pull. It is harder to train hounds than it is to train Siberian Huskies and Malamutes to pull a sled because it is not in their nature. Training should start at around six months of age by pulling a small log behind them.{{citation needed|date=February 2017}}
==Gallery== <gallery mode=packed> File:Dog sled quebec 2010.JPG|Dog sled in [[Quebec]] Image:Engagé mit einem indianischen Hundeschlitten by Maximilian zu Wied-Neuwied.jpg|Indian dog sled near [[Fort Clark Trading Post State Historic Site|Fort Clark]]. Watercolor by [[Prince Maximilian of Wied-Neuwied]] 1833 Image:MOHAI Alaska glass.jpg|[[Stained glass]] [[Alaska]]n theme, formerly part of a [[Seattle]] storefront, now in the [[Museum of History and Industry]] Image:ADK Museum - Dog Sled.jpg|Antique dog sled at the [[Adirondack Museum]] File:dog sled kennels.JPG|Commercial sled dog kennels </gallery>

'''Enercoop''' is a French [[electric utility]] cooperative company, which only uses [[renewable energy]]. It is the only one in France in the form of a [[cooperative]]. Its founding members include [[Greenpeace]] and other proponents of [[environmental protection]] and the ethical economy, such as ''La Nef'', a French [[cooperative bank]] and the [[Friends of the Earth]] association.<ref>[[:fr:Enercoop]]</ref> As of mid-2014, Enercoop has {{formatnum:20000}} clients<ref>http://france3-regions.francetvinfo.fr/aquitaine/2014/04/04/enercoop-fournisseur-d-electricite-verte-s-installe-en-aquitaine-453247.html</ref>
==History== Enercoop was created in 2005 and initially, as the French electricity market wasn't yet liberalized, Enercoop just had companies as clients. Later on, in 2007, as the market was liberalized, Enercoop started to grow and totalized more than {{formatnum:200}} clients.
In 2011, after the [[Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster]], Enercoop went from {{formatnum:3000}} clients in 2009 to {{formatnum:10000}} in late 2011.
Nowadays, in 2014, Enercoop has {{formatnum:20000}} clients.
==Objectives== Its aim is to create many regional cooperatives around France where the local members can be in charge of all parts of the energy process from production to consumption. In this way the group intends to make citizens responsible for the energy they consume. Actually, in 2014, it has 6 regional cooperatives.
Enercoop's [[articles of association]] impose that at least 57% of the profits must be reinvested in means of electricity production. The remaining profits can either be reinvested or can reward its investors.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Portal|France|Energy|Companies}} * {{Official website|http://www.enercoop.fr}}
[[Category:Energy cooperatives]] [[Category:Renewable energy companies of France]] [[Category:French companies established in 2005]] [[Category:Energy companies established in 2005]] [[Category:Renewable resource companies established in 2005]] [[Category:Cooperatives in France]]

revision.text:
The '''Fuel Freedom Foundation''' was officially launched in October 2012 by entrepreneurs Joseph Hollander<ref>http://www.fuelfreedom.org/who-we-are/executive-leadership/</ref> and Eyal Aronoff.<ref>http://www.fuelfreedom.org/tag/eyal-aronoff/</ref><ref>Cook, B.W. [http://www.dailypilot.com/entertainment/tn-dpt-1025-cook-20121024,0,5959135.story "The Crowd: Big names fighting fuel dependence"], [[Daily Pilot]], October 24, 2012</ref> The foundation has a mission to end the United States' dependence on oil by removing barriers to competition in the [[transportation]] fuel market. The founders believe that fuel prices could be permanently reduced to below $1 a gallon.<ref>http://www.fuelfreedom.org/angry-rising-gas-prices-something/</ref>
The foundation's Board of Advisors includes former CIA Director [[R. James Woolsey, Jr.]], former New Mexico Governor [[Bill Richardson]],<ref>[https://www.wsj.com/article/PR-CO-20130422-905286.html?mod=googlenews_wsj "Governor Bill Richardson Joins Fuel Freedom Foundation's Board of Advisors"]{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', April 22, 2013</ref> former president of the Rockefeller Foundation Peter Goldmark,<ref>[http://www.marketwatch.com/story/fuel-freedom-foundation-launches-campaign-to-end-americas-oil-addiction-2012-10-22 "Fuel Freedom Foundation Launches Campaign to End America's Oil Addiction"] [[MarketWatch]], October 22, 2012 {{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> former dean of the University of Colorado's Graduate School of Public Policy Marshall Kaplan,<ref>[http://www.c-spanvideo.org/marshallkaplan "C-SPAN Biographical History"], [[C-SPAN]]</ref> former president of Shell Oil Company [[John Hofmeister]]<ref>[http://www.hybridcars.com/john-hofmeister-joins-fuel-freedom-foundation/ "John Hofmeister Joins Fuel Freedom Foundation"], "Hybrid Cars", April 5, 2013</ref> and Co-director of the Institute for the Analysis of Global Security Gal Luft.<ref>[http://www.iags.org/galluft.htm "Institute for the Analysis of Global Security"], [[Institute for the Analysis of Global Security]]</ref> The CEO is [[Joseph A. Cannon]].
==Outlook and goals== The foundation believes that high [[oil price]]s are a result of a systematic [[monopoly]]. Contrary to a more traditional monopoly, where one company has a large enough market share to control prices, the oil-market is believed to be a monopolistic market because oil is the primary, and in most cases the only, fuel for transportation. These monopolistic forces create a situation where oil expenditures in the U.S. top $780 billion per year, more than twenty times the amount spent on coal.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iKEtQ_zz4GA "Ending Our Oil Addiction: Yossie Hollander at TEDxChapmanU"], [[TEDx]], July 5, 2012</ref>
According to the Foundation, outdated regulations prevent drivers from making simple modifications to their engines that would enable their cars to run on alternatives fuels, hence threatening oil's monopoly over the transportation fuel market.<ref>[https://www.cnbc.com/id/100617230 "Our Real Energy Problem, and How We Solve It"], [[CNBC]], April 4, 2013</ref> Updating these regulations to allow for current vehicles to modify their engines would allow for a near-term, widespread expansion of fuel choice for drivers.<ref>[https://www.economist.com/blogs/babbage/2012/08/alternative-fuels "Difference Engine: Competition At The Pump"], [[The Economist]], August 20, 2012</ref> [[Ethanol]], [[methanol]], [[natural gas]] and [[electric car]]s are seen as viable replacement fuels to compete against oil in an open market. No one fuel is explicitly favored over the others but most people believe methanol made from [[natural gas]] holds the most promise to break oil's monopoly.<ref name="Tucker">Tucker, William [http://www.realclearenergy.org/articles/2012/11/19/can_two_softward_geeks_free_us_from_foreign_oil_106784.html "Can Two Software Geeks Save Us From Foreign Oil?"], "Real Clear Energy", November 19, 2012</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.fuelfreedom.org/ FuelFreedom.org] * [http://www.facebook.com/FuelFreedomFoundation/ Fuel Freedom Foundation on Facebook]

page.title: Harvard Medical School Center for Health and the Global Environment

revision.text:
'''The Center for Health and the Global Environment''' is located at the [[Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health]]. The mission of the Center is to help people understand that our health, and that of our children, depends on the health of the environment, and that we must do everything we can to protect it. It bestows the [[Global Environmental Citizen Award]] annually upon an individual working to protect the environment.
The Center was founded in 1996, at [[Harvard Medical School]], to promote a wider understanding of the human health consequences of global environmental change. The Center moved to the Harvard Chan School in October 2012.{{cn|date=May 2018}}
To realize the mission and catalyze change, the Center:
* Conducts research and translate knowledge into concrete, personal terms that everyone can relate to. * Informs policy by bringing the latest and best science into legislative decisions. * Convenes today’s thought leaders to advance strategies for creating a healthy world. * Educates and inspires tomorrow’s leaders so that they may influence the direction of their chosen fields towards a more sustainable future. * Empowers key stakeholders to make decisions that will protect for our health and the health of the environment.
In May 2018, it launched the Center for Climate, Health, and the Global Environment (C-CHANGE)<ref>{{cite web |title=Gina McCarthy, former U.S. EPA Administrator, launches C-CHANGE at Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health |url=https://www.hsph.harvard.edu/news/press-releases/gina-mccarthy-c-change-launch-harvard-chan-school/ |website=News |accessdate=31 May 2018 |date=30 May 2018}}</ref>, directed by former EPA Administrator [[Gina McCarthy]].<ref name="Gina McCarthy May 31 op-ed">{{cite web |last1=McCarthy |first1=Gina |title=It's Time To Take Climate Change Personally |url=http://www.wbur.org/cognoscenti/2018/05/31/global-warming-harvard-gina-mccarthy |website=www.wbur.org |accessdate=31 May 2018 |language=en}}</ref>
==Programs== * Climate, Energy, and Health * Corporate Sustainability and Health * Executive Education for Sustainability Leadership * Healthy and Sustainable Food * International Sustainable Tourism Initiative * Nature, Health, and the Built Environment * Sustainable Technologies and Health
==References== <references />
==External links== * [http://www.chgeharvard.org Home page]
{{environment-org-stub}}
[[Category:Harvard School of Public Health]]

{{Multiple issues| {{unbalanced|date=October 2012}} {{disputed|date=October 2012}} }} {{Coord|26.020438|107.077246|format=dms|type:landmark_region:CN-52_source:Gaode|display=title}}
'''Hidden Character Stone''' ({{zh|c=藏字石 / 救星石 |p=cángzì shí / jiùxīng shí}}) is a stone located in a scenic spot area in the town of [[Zhangbu]] ({{lang|zh-hans|[[:zh:掌布镇|掌布镇]]}}), [[Pingtang County]], [[Qiannan Buyei and Miao Autonomous Prefecture]], [[Guizhou]]. The stone displays patterns on its surface that have been interpreted as [[Simplified Chinese characters]] and [[Traditional Chinese characters]], and have been read as "[[Communist Party of China]]" ({{lang|zh-hant|中國共產党}}), or alternatively as "Communist Party of China perish" ({{lang|zh-hant|中國共產党亡}}).<ref name="s8">{{cite web|url=http://s8int.com/page28.html |title=Mysterious "Two-Hundred Million-Year-Old" Hidden Stone Bears the Words: "Chinese Communist Party Collapses" Page 28 |publisher=S8int.com |date= |accessdate=2011-06-27}}</ref>
==Area== Hidden Character Stone is a main attraction along with a jade water basin (玉水金盆) that is part of the Qiannan Pingtang National Geological Park (黔南平塘地质公园).<ref name="lc" /> The park has an area of about 201.6 square kilometers.<ref name="lc">{{cite news|url=http://life.chinatimes.com/2009Cti/Channel/Life/life-article/0,5047,11051801+112011060200077,00.html |title=新民晚報－貴州平塘 玉水金盆處處景 |publisher=Life.chinatimes.com |date=2011-06-02 |accessdate=2011-06-27}}</ref> The stone is in a narrow gap between two cliffs, just wide enough for two people.<ref name="s8" />
==History== {{Weasel words|date=February 2017}} In June 2002, the [[Duyun]] international photography exposition (都匀国际摄影博览会) recommended an area in Zhangbu as a photo spot.<ref name="sohu1">{{cite web|url=http://news.sohu.com/20060427/n243019837.shtml |title=贵州藏字石（神州搜奇）(组图)-搜狐新闻 |publisher=News.sohu.com |date=2007-04-02 |accessdate=2011-06-27}}</ref> The stone was discovered during cleanup after the expo. The area has been isolated, untouched by humans for a long time. <ref name="s8" /> The person cleaning the area was staff member Wang Guo-fu (王国富), who discovered the characters written on the stone.<ref name="xin1">{{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/newscenter/2003-12/08/content_1220053.htm |title=2.7亿年"中国共产党"字样地质奇观惊现贵州(图) |publisher=News.xinhuanet.com |date=2003-12-08 |accessdate=2011-06-27}}</ref>
From December 5–8, 2003 a Chinese scientific inspection group was formed to investigate the stone with about 15 scientists.<ref name="s8" /> Some of the notables include Li Ting-dong (李廷栋) from Chinese Academy of Sciences, Liu Bao-jun (刘宝君) from Chinese academy of Sciences and Li Feng-lin (李凤麟) from China University of Geosciences.<ref name="dongt">{{cite web|url=http://www.dongtaiwang.com/dm/uGGc/o5.xNaMUBaTThb.pbz/abqr/402546 |title=看中國 - 《新看點》：懸疑！從貴州藏字石到太湖冤魂、安陽靈異案(圖) |publisher=Dongtaiwang.com |date= |accessdate=2011-06-27}}</ref> The stone was analyzed to be about 270 million years old from the [[Permian]] period.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.china.com.cn/v/2008-02/13/content_9675017.htm |title=2.7亿年前的藏字石谜_视频中国_中国网 |publisher=China.com.cn |date=2008-02-13 |accessdate=2011-06-27}}</ref> There are no traces of the characters being made by humans.<ref name="s8" /> Other researchers included Li Feng-lin (李鳳麟) and Gu Jing-yi (賈精一).<ref name="ATVfiles">ATV China's mystery files (中國神祕檔案) episode on save star stone</ref>
Li Ting-dong further commented about the stone's contribution to science, and that there is nothing like it. Liu Bao-jun further support additional research to be done and was interested in the natural formation of the characters on the stone.<ref>http://www.ptjp.gov.cn/gzpt/wh/2010/56/10_5_6_10_28_12_65BE2_2.html</ref> Each character on the stone is about one square [[shaku (unit)|shaku]], which is about 1 square foot.<ref name="sohu1" />
==Description==
===Five-character version=== The five-character version suggests the characters on the stone said "Communist Party of China" (中国共产党). This is the version publicly accepted in the PRC. Also when referring to this version, the stone has been called (救星石), literally "savior stone". This name comes from people who are passionate in supporting and admire the Communist Party.<ref name="xin1" /><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.sohu.com/20090915/n266743341.shtml |title="救星石" 两亿七千万年的神秘天书-搜狐新闻 |publisher=News.sohu.com |date= |accessdate=2011-06-27}}</ref> The story of how the stone was discovered usually follows this version.<ref name="sohu1" /> Zhang Dahua (张大华) of Zhangbu village once publicly gave an explanation of how the name "savior stone" was created.<ref name="ATVfiles" />
===Six-character version=== The six-character version suggests the characters on the stone said "Communist Party of China perish" (中国共产党亡).<ref name="s8" /> There has been criticism that the sixth and last character "perish" (亡) has been purposely neglected to turn a "Perish communist stone" (亡共石) into a "savior stone".<ref>{{cite web|author=作者：华风 |url=http://renminbao.com/rmb/articles/2005/5/26/36082.html |title="亡共石"变"救星石"趣谈 (图) |publisher=Renminbao.com |date= |accessdate=2011-06-27}}</ref> This is not a version accepted in the PRC, hence when mainland media reports it, it has to hide the perish character.<ref name="dongt" /> Often when pictures are shown with the stone having six characters, the description still refers to it by the five-character version.<ref name="sohu1" /> In Chinese text the character "perish" (亡) is often used in association with the perish of a state like "[[Chu (state)|Chu]] perish" (楚亡), "[[Wei (state)|Wei]] perish" (魏亡).<ref>劉煒/著. [2002] (2002) Chinese civilization in a new light 中華文明傳真#3 春秋戰國. Publishing Company. {{ISBN|962-07-5311-9}}. Book end time line.</ref>
===Traditional and Simplified Chinese=== The characters on the stone are a mix of [[Traditional Chinese characters]] and [[Simplified Chinese characters]]. The first and third character ({{lang|zh|{{linktext|中}}}}, {{lang|zh|{{linktext|共}}}}) are identical in both versions. The second character "country" ({{lang|zh-hant|{{linktext|國}}}}) and fourth character "produce" ({{lang|zh-hant|{{linktext|產}}}}) is in the traditional form. The fifth character, "party" ({{lang|zh-hans|{{linktext|党}}}}) is in the simplified form.<ref name="sina1">{{cite web|url=http://news.sina.com.cn/o/2005-03-01/07135229255s.shtml |script-title=zh:惊看平塘"藏字石"(图)_新闻中心_新浪网 |publisher=News.sina.com.cn |date=2005-03-10 |accessdate=2011-06-27}}</ref> The sixth character "perish" ({{lang|zh|{{linktext|亡}}}}) has no difference. Some have analyzed all the odd characters as Simplified, while the even characters are Traditional.<ref name="ATVfiles" />
* On the stone: {{lang|zh|中國共產党亡}} * Traditional Chinese: {{lang|zh-hant|中國共產黨亡}} * Simplified Chinese: {{lang|zh-hans|中国共产党亡}}
===Analysis=== The origin of the characters remain a subject of dispute.<ref name="scholar">{{cite journal| title=平塘掌布藏字石发现经历|url=http://www.xzbu.com/4/view-3821203.htm|author=Mao, Jianquan|journal=贵阳文史|volume=6|pages=25|year=2012}}</ref> There were some early speculations that the characters were put there by the [[People's Liberation Army]], but according to the path of the [[Long March]], they never went to Pingtang.<ref name="ATVfiles" /> The characters also read left to right, which was not practiced at the time. The inclusion of a Simplified character before the CPC did any simplifications also ruled them out.<ref name="ATVfiles" /> There were also some skeptics who suspected the village was creating a fraud to build their tourism industry at the time.<ref name="ATVfiles" />Others think the Hidden Character Stone was made in the [[Cultural Revolution]].<ref>[http://gzczs.guiyangbus.com/gzczs/002.html 贵州藏字石-见解] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120118023221/http://gzczs.guiyangbus.com/gzczs/002.html |date=2012-01-18 }}</ref>
==Cultural reference== The Hidden Character Stone has appeared as a topic on a number of shows such as [[China Central Television|CCTV]]'s "Approaching Science" (走近科学) and the [[Hong Kong]] [[Asia Television|ATV]] show "China's Mystery Files" (中國神祕檔案).<ref>http://www.ptjp.gov.cn/gzpt/wh/2010/510/10_5_10_11_37_2_76G39.html</ref> Both refer to the five-character version.
==References== {{reflist|2}}
[[Category:2002 in China]] [[Category:2003 in China]] [[Category:Archaeological artifacts of China]] [[Category:Out-of-place artifacts]] [[Category:Stones]] [[Category:2002 archaeological discoveries]]

The '''Hydrologic Evaluation of Landfill Performance''' ('''HELP''') model is a quasi-two-dimensional [[hydrology|hydrologic]] [[Scientific modelling|numerical model]] for conducting water balance analysis of [[landfill]]s, cover systems, and other solid waste containment facilities; it was developed for the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency]].<ref name="schroeder94">{{cite book |author=Schroeder, P.R., Dozier, T.S., Zappi, P.A., McEnroe, B.M., Sjostrom, J.W. and Peyton, R.L. |year=1994 |title=The Hydrologic Evaluation of Landfill Performance (HELP) model: Engineering documentation for version 3 |publisher=U.S. Environmental Protection Agency Risk Reduction Engineering Laboratory |location=Cincinnati, OH}}</ref>
==Versions== *Public domain (free) version: **[https://www.epa.gov/land-research/hydrologic-evaluation-landfill-performance-help-model HELP 3.07] – [[DOS]] [[executable]], as well as most of the [[Fortran]] [[source code]] and user manuals<ref name="schroeder94" /> *Commercial versions: **[https://www.waterloohydrogeologic.com/visual-help/ Visual HELP] – based on the HELP version 3.07, offers a [[Microsoft Windows]] [[GUI]] to view and edit soil profiles and to generate weather data. **[https://www.geo.uni-hamburg.de/en/bodenkunde/service/help-model.html HELP 3.95 D] – by Dr. Klaus Berger at the [[University of Hamburg]]; offers a [[Microsoft Windows]] UI and includes the model HELP 3.07 and the enhanced model HELP 3.95 D.
==References== <references/>
[[Category:Landfill]] [[Category:Hydrology models]]

InMotion is a student team focused in electric racing and [[fast charging]]. InMotion is based in [[Helmond]] and is composed mostly of students from the [[Eindhoven University of Technology]] and [[Fontys University of Applied Sciences]]. The team was founded in 2012 by Albert Maas under the guidance of [[Maarten Steinbuch]] <ref>InMotion,[ https://www.inmotion.tue.nl/en/ourstory "How it All Began"]</ref>. In 2017, the Fusion, the team’s first car, was built<ref>InMotion,[ https://www.inmotion.tue.nl/en/ourstory "How it All Began"]</ref>. The Fusion is an electric formula car and holds the electric lap record in [[Circuit Zandvoort]] <ref>[ https://www.cursor.tue.nl/en/news/2017/juni/inmotion-smashes-electric-track-record-at-zandvoort/ Article in ''Cursor'']</ref>, [[Circuit Zolder]] <ref>[ https://www.cursor.tue.nl/en/news/2017/juli/inmotion-adds-electric-record-in-zolder-to-its-haul/ Article in ''Cursor'']</ref> and [[TT Circuit Assen]] <ref>[ https://ict.eu/2018/een-nieuw-ronderecord-voor-inmotion-op-ciruit-assen/ Article in ''ICT'']</ref>. The team is currently developing an endurance race car, the Vision. The goal is to develop the first fully electric car to compete in the [[24 Hours of Le Mans]], in the Garage 56 class <ref>[ https://www.inmotion.tue.nl/en/cars2/vision Article in ''InMotion'']</ref> <ref>[ https://www.studio040.nl/inmotion-24-uur-van-le-mans-is-middel-oplossing-elektrisch-rijden-is-doel/content/item?1101258 Article in ''Studio 040'']</ref>.
==Cars of InMotion== ===Ignition=== In 2009, a group of students from the University of Applied Sciences of Utrecht presented their graduation project: an eco-friendly formula race car, the Formula Bio. Their dream was to participate in the [[Formula Student]], a race similar to Formula 1, only for students. The Formula Bio stood for environmentally friendly and inexpensive race cars. After they graduated, one of the group members went to study at [[Eindhoven University of Technology]]. This student, Albert Maas, came into contact with [[Maarten Steinbuch]] <ref>InMotion,[ https://www.inmotion.tue.nl/en/ourstory "How it All Began"]</ref>. Together they came up with the idea of participating in the [[24 Hours of Le Mans]] with a fully electric car. In 2012, the InMotion student team was officially established.
===Fusion=== [[File:Beitske Visser in the InMotion IM-e 2017.jpg|thumb|right|400px|The Fusion with [[Beitske Visser]] behind the wheel.]] The Fusion is the fastest electric formula car in the world, with a top speed of 246 km/h. The Fusion is built to break track records of circuits, and not to fit into a particular ranking, so the car does not have to meet certain restrictions. How is the car so fast? This is due to a combination of different techniques. The [[propulsion]] is important, and also the aerodynamics of the car. The small size of the car also plays a role. Below are some facts to get a better understanding of the Fusion. * The car weighs 650 [[kilos]] in total, of which the monocoque weighs 60 kilos * The Fusion has reached a maximum speed of 246 kilometers per hour * The full power of the car is 400 [[kW]]
The InMotion team launched its first full electric racing car in 2016. The car was based on the former Formula Bio car has been built on a [[carbon fiber]] chassis. The full electric engine has a better power to weight ratio compared to a [[Formula E]] car.<ref>{{cite web|title=IM/e|url=http://inmotion.tue.nl/kpt-ime/|website=InMotion|accessdate=1 September 2017}}</ref> The car made its track debut at [[Circuit Zandvoort]] during the [[2016 Masters of Formula 3]] event. Drivers [[Xavier Maassen]] and [[Jan Lammers]] gave the car a shakedown.<ref>{{cite web|title=InMotion|url=https://www.tue.nl/tue-campus/tue-innovation-lab/where-science-meets-business-innovatie-door-co-creatie/maak-kennis-met-de-studententeams/inmotion/#top|website=TU/e|accessdate=1 September 2017}}</ref> In 2017 [[USF2000]] driver [[Rinus van Kalmthout]] did a straight line test at the Automotive Campus [[Helmond]] test track (part of the [[List of motorways in the Netherlands|A270 motorway]]). During the year the team improved track records for electric cars at two tracks. [[Beitske Visser]] improved the record at Zandvoort.<ref>{{cite web|title=Studententeam uit Eindhoven verbetert elektrisch ronderecord Circuit Zandvoort|url=https://nl.motorsport.com/general/news/studententeam-eindhoven-verbreekt-elektrisch-ronderecord-circuit-zandvoort-913954/|website=Motorsport.nl|accessdate=1 September 2017}}</ref> Testdriver Maassen beat the track record for electric cars at [[Circuit Zolder]], previously held by Bert Longin in a [[Tesla Roadster (2008)|Tesla Roadster]].<ref>{{cite web|title=IM/e verpulvert elektrisch ronderecord Circuit Zolder|url=https://www.autosport.be/news/im-e-verpulvert-elektrisch-ronderecord-circuit-zolder.html|website=Autosport.be|accessdate=1 September 2017}}</ref>
====Aerodynamics==== :Keeping the test platform on the road requires a lot of downward pressure. The most important parts of the car that generate this pressure are the [[Diffuser (automotive)|diffuser]], the [[front wing]] and the [[rear wing]]. The diffuser is the floor plate of the car, which is shaped so that it creates a lower pressure under the car and thus generates downforce. The rear wing consists of three elements, one of which is adjustable. The front wing is similar. Both wings can be removed from the car so that the aerodynamics specialists can test them and gain more insight into the air flows. This is mainly done with the program ANSYS Fluent, using simulations to investigate aerodynamics. Then the data is supplemented with results from our test drives.
====Monocoque==== :The [[monocoque]] is made of a composite with sandwich structure, which is also used in other open wheel race cars. The monocoque is not only made for drivers of average length, but even for drivers up to just under 2 meters. The total weight of the chassis is only 60 kilograms, including the bulkhead and the paint. The drivers all have her or his own pre-formed seat, making them comfortable and protected against unexpected movements.
====Propulsion==== :The [[propulsion]] is one of the main reasons why this car is so fast. Our battery pack is about 1/3 of the total weight of the car. The Fusion has rear-wheel drive, with two Yasa 750-series engines. At the [[Circuit Zandvoort]] the car achieved a maximum speed of 246 kilometers per hour. In addition, various safety measures have been taken to ensure safety. The battery pack is constantly monitored by the [[battery management system]], and at the smallest deviation the current is removed.
====Electronic control unit (ECU)==== :The car contains many sensors that measure parameters such as temperature and resistance, and which register data for the models. By connecting the ECU to our computer you can read these measurements. ICT Automatizing and InMotion have designed the ECUs for the Ignition together. ICT has given the access to their Motar platform, which consists of the hardware and software of the ECU. InMotion has created the control algorithms in MATLAB and Simulink. With the Motar-Toolbox they can generate production class software based on AUTOSAR of the model at the touch of a button.
===Vision=== The Vision is a fully electric [[Le Mans prototype]] under development. Unlike the Fusion, this car is also built for its [[endurance]]. The Vision will be unique because it will be the first fully electric race car to participate in the 24 Hours of Le Mans. In the Garage 56 category, InMotion can use the innovative technological developments to make the race car as fast and environmentally friendly as possible. Engineers of the team have already thought about the following topics for the Vision: fan system for downforce, suspension, electric powertrain, aerodynamics and the monocoque. The team has gained knowledge about most of these topics by building the Ignition and the Fusion. Furthermore, there have been several graduation projects on various topics regarding the Vision. The most important difference between these cars and the Vision is the focus on charging time. The [[concept car]] is an embodiment of the future for [[electric driving]]. The ultimate goal of the team is thus literally visible and tangible. The aerodynamics of the concept car have already been carefully thought out and designed by the team.
The concept car is the embodiment of future electric mobility. The ultimate end goal of the team is now made attainable. The outline of the concept car has been carefully designed and engineered by the team. Making the end goal closer to reality, by our team tackling the primary technical challenge, charging times.
==Student team== Passion and ambition are the great motivations of the student team. The team consists of full-time members, part-time members, and trainees. Together, from all kinds of different disciplines, they work on one mission. The uniqueness of the InMotion student team is the ultimate goal, not an annual project. Everyone who has worked with them is seen as part of the team.
In addition, the team receives regular advice from the 'technical advisory board' and 'supervisory board'. The Supervisory Board ensures that the project continues to follow a uniform line over the years. The technical advisory board consists of experienced members who meet weekly with the current engineers in order to guarantee the transfer of knowledge and to help with problems.

revision.text:
{{Infobox Officeholder |name = Massimo Aparo
{{lang|it|Massimo Aparo}} |image = Gill Tudor, Massimo Aparo & Serge Gas (01611288) (11101709704).jpg |office = Deputy Director General of International Atomic Energy Agency |term_start = 11 May 2018 |term_end = Up to Now |predecessor =: Tero Varjoranta , [[Finland]] |successor = |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1953|7|31|df=y}}Facebook |birth_place = [[Italy]] |death_date = |death_place = |party = |alma_mater = :A nuclear engineer, graduated from Sapienza University of Rome }} '''Massimo Aparo''' (born 31 July 1953) is an [[Italian language|Italian ]] [[diplomat]], who started working as acting deputy director general and head of the Department of Safeguards, after [[Tero Varjoranta]] has resigned effective 11 May 2018. [https://www.iaea.org/about/organizational-structure/department-of-safeguards/deputy-director-general-of-department-of-safeguards Massimo Aparo][https://af.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idAFKBN1IC22A U.N. nuclear watchdog's inspections chief quits suddenly][https://nypost.com/2018/05/12/uns-top-nuclear-inspector-suddenly-quits-as-trump-pulls-out-of-iran-deal/ UN’s top nuke inspector abruptly quits days after US pulls out of Iran deal][https://www.straitstimes.com/world/europe/chief-inspector-of-un-nuclear-watchdog-resigns Chief inspector of UN nuclear watchdog resigns][http://www.newindianexpress.com/world/2018/may/12/uns-top-nuclear-inspector-tero-varjorantas-sudden-resignation-lands-iran-in-focus-again-1813746.html UN's top nuclear inspector Tero Varjoranta's sudden resignation lands Iran in focus again][http://www.delta-optimist.com/un-s-top-nuclear-inspector-resigns-suddenly-1.23300540 UN's top nuclear inspector resigns suddenly][http://thehill.com/policy/international/387422-top-un-nuclear-official-resigns-suddenly-report Top UN nuclear official abruptly resigns] ==Biography== Massimo Aparo was born in [[Pistoia]]. He is a nuclear engineer and was graduated from Sapienza [[University of Rome Tor Vergata|University of Rome]]. Aparo, before joining the [[International Atomic Energy Agency]] (IAEA) worked as Director General of an Italian company in the area of radiation detection and monitoring, in the [[European Space Agency]] and at Italy’s former National Committee for Nuclear Energy. [http://www.ansa.it/sito/notizie/mondo/2018/05/11/nucleare-si-dimette-direttore-aiea_7f783be5-7073-4a60-b2cc-fcbb146eb1af.html Nucleare: si dimette direttore Aiea][https://www.corriere.it/cronache/18_maggio_11/nucleare-si-dimette-direttore-aiea-carica-italiano-aparo-aa654802-5552-11e8-bf97-5f8d4271ee5b.shtml Nucleare: si dimette il capo degli ispettori Aiea, al suo posto l'italiano Aparo][https://www.jaea.go.jp/04/iscn/activity/2008-06-24/2008-06-24-0-5.pdf Safety and Security] ==Career== He was appointed Acting Deputy Director General and Head of the Department of Safeguards in the IAEA on 11 May 2018 by the [[Yukiya Amano]] Director General of [[IAEA safeguards|IAEA]]. Before this date, he occupied the position of Acting Director of the Office for Verification in [[Iran]]. Aparo started working in the [[IAEA safeguards|IAEA Safeguards]] Department since 1997. He served in the following positions: * Section Head of the Division of Technical and Scientific Services, [http://www.presstv.com/Detail/2018/05/11/561409/IAEA-Tero-Varjoranta-resignation-JCPOA-Iran-US-Trump IAEA says agency’s chief inspector resigns after US pullout of Iran deal] * Head of the [[Tokyo]] Regional Office in the Division of Operations A, and * Head of the Iran Task Force [https://www.iaea.org/about/organizational-structure/department-of-safeguards Department of Safeguards] Before joining the IAEA, Aparo worked as director general of an Italian firm specialized in radiation [[detection]] and [[Monitoring control and surveillance|monitoring]]. He also has the experience of working in the [[European Space Agency]] and at the Italian Nuclear Energy Commission. ==Iran Task Force== Aparo, is the leader of an elite unit of the International Atomic Energy Agency known as Iran Task Force. It was created three years ago by IAEA’s director-general, Japanese diplomat [[Yukiya Amano]]. The task force consists of around 50 members, including [[Nuclear engineering|nuclear engineers]], [[Chemist|chemists]], [[Physicist|physicists]], intelligence data analysts and communication experts. According to [[the Jerusalem Post]], “The Iran Task Force is part of the IAEA’s Department of Safeguards and Verification, which is in charge of making sure that all its state members properly use [[nuclear technology]] and know-how for the declared [[civilian]] and peaceful purposes: [[scientific research]],” [https://www.iaea.org/newscenter/news/new-iaea-uranium-enrichment-monitor-verify-iran’s-commitments-under-jcpoa New IAEA Uranium Enrichment Monitor to Verify Iran’s Commitments under JCPOA][https://www.iaea.org/newscenter/focus/iran/chronology-of-key-events IAEA and Iran: Chronology of Key Events][https://www.jpost.com/International/Intelligence-file-Over-to-the-inspectors-408561 Intelligence file: Over to the inspectors] ==See also== * [[Radiation and Nuclear Safety Authority]] * [[IAEA safeguards]] * [[International Commission on Radiological Protection]] * [[International Atomic Energy Agency]] * [[Yukiya Amano]] * [[Tero Varjoranta]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} [[Category:Italian diplomats]] [[Category:Nuclear proliferation]] [[Category:Italian officials of the United Nations]] [[Category:Nuclear power]] [[Category:Nuclear weapons policy]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People associated with nuclear power]] [[Category:1956 births]]

revision.text:
The '''mean annual increment''' (MAI) or '''mean annual growth''' refers to the average growth per year a tree or stand of trees has exhibited/experienced to a specified age. For example, a 20-year-old tree that has a [[diameter at breast height]] (dbh) of 10.0 inches has an MAI of 0.5 inches/year. MAI is calculated as <math>MAI=Y(t)/t</math> where Y(t) = yield at time t. Because the typical growth patterns of most trees is [[sigmoid function|sigmoidal]], the MAI starts out small, increases to a maximum value as the tree matures, then declines slowly over the remainder of the tree's life. Throughout this, the MAI always remains positive. MAI differs from [[periodic annual increment]] (PAI) because the PAI is simply the growth for one specific year or any other specified length of time. [[Image:Sheet4 Chart 5.JPG|right|thumb|MAI vs PAI]]
The point where the MAI and PAI meet is typically referred to as the [[biological rotation age]]. This is the age at which the tree or stand would be harvested if the management objective is to maximize long-term yield. The proof of this definition is shown by differentiating MAI(t) with respect to t, and is shown by Husch, Miller, and Beers <ref>Husch, B., Miller, C.I., and T.W. Beers. 1982. Forest Mensuration. Wiley. New York. 402 p.</ref>
==References == <references/> [https://web.archive.org/web/20080627105807/http://www.mongabay.com/reference/environment/Mean_Annual_Increment.html Mean Annual Increment]
Avery and Burkhart. ''Forest Measurements''. Fifth Edition, McGraw Hill, New York. 2002.

revision.text:
The '''multiple integrated laser engagement system''', or '''MILES''', is used by the [[United States armed forces|U.S. military]] and other armed forces around the world for training purposes. It uses [[laser]]s and [[Blank (cartridge)|blank cartridge]]s to simulate actual battle.
Individual soldiers carry small laser [[sensor]]s scattered over their bodies, which detect when the soldier has been illuminated by a firearm's laser. Each laser transmitter is set to mimic the effective range of the weapon on which it is used. When a person is "hit", a medic can use the digital readout to determine which first aid method to practice.
Different versions of MILES systems are available to both US and international militaries. The capabilities of the individual systems can vary significantly but in general all modern systems carry information about the shooter, weapon and ammunition in the laser. When this information is received by the target, the target's MILES system uses a random number roll and a casualty probability [[lookup table]] to determine the outcome. For example, a MILES transmitter emulating an [[M16 rifle]] cannot harm an armored personnel carrier (APC), but could still "kill" a commander visible in the hatch of the vehicle.
Vehicles are typically outfitted with a belt of laser sensors or individual wireless detectors. Dismounted soldiers often wear a vest or harness with sensors as well as a "halo" of sensors on their helmets. MILES systems can be coupled with a real-time data link allowing position and event data to be transmitted back to a central site for data collection and display. More sophisticated systems for tanks and APCs exist that use various techniques (including scanning lasers and coupled radio systems) to allow more precise targeting of armored vehicles.
The standard is maintained by the [[United States Army|U.S. Army's]] PEO-STRI branch.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.peostri.army.mil/PRODUCTS/MCC/|title=Multiple Integrated Laser Engagement System (MILES) Communication Code (MCC) Standard|work=United States Army|accessdate=17 February 2013}}</ref>
==Early versions== [[File:Fibua.jpg|thumb|MILES simulation (note the laser emitters attached to the rifles' barrels, and the laser receptors on the soldiers' helmets and harnesses).]] [[File:Polish AKMS.JPEG|thumb|Polish Soldier with MILES gear, AKMS and three magazines taped together [[jungle style]].]]
MILES was introduced to the [[United States Army|U.S. Army]] for direct-fire, force-on-force training capability at home stations and combat training centers during operational testing in 1978 and 1979 following the conclusion of the US Army's Engineering Development program awarded to Xerox Electro-Optical Systems. The goal of the program was to design and build a tactical training system that simulates the weapons, weapon characteristics and effects of a family of weapon systems including infantry, armor and aircraft, with an initial design of 11 systems including rifles, tank guns, and missiles.<ref>Trainer Engineering Report for MILES, Vol. I, Xerox Electro-Optical Systems, Contract No. N61139-76-C-0060</ref>
MILES systems used a laser module which was mounted to the barrel of a real weapon, a [[blank-firing adaptor]] for the weapon, and an integrated receiver consisting of sensors on the helmet and load-bearing vests of the soldiers. When a blank shot was fired by a weapon, it caused the laser to fire a coded burst in the direction that the weapon was aimed. If that burst was sensed by the receiver of another soldier, the "hit" soldier's gear beacon made a beeping noise to let them know they were "dead". MILES had serious problems—when hit, the receiver did not prevent the further firing of the weapon, and it was tempting and easy for soldiers to "cheat" by turning the receivers off and back on again, resetting the system and therefore "[[spawning (video gaming)|respawning]]" or "resurrecting" themselves. In addition, no data about the engagement was kept so it was impossible to positively identify who shot whom on the battlefield, a critical piece of information when attempting to develop new tactics. MILES was also very encumbering and soldiers sometimes experienced neck pain when using it.
In 1981, Simulaser Corporation was founded by two entrepreneur engineers and began operations near Los Angeles to develop "Advanced MILES" training systems<ref>"The New Entrepreneurs," Electronic Engineering Times, July 19, 1982</ref>. Under initial contracts from Sandia National Labs, Simulaser produced standard MILES replacement laser transmitters and man-worn detector systems as well as "Advanced MILES" devices that incorporated player identification and scoring systems. These Advanced MILES systems made use of the CMOS 146800-series embedded controllers that had just become available at that time. The systems interleaved unique player identification codes within the weapon code bits transmitted by the laser, which were then stored by the receiver system of any player that was hit<ref>"Laser Battlefield Simulation Reaches New Levels of Sophistication", Military Electronics/Countermeasures, February 1983</ref>. Those systems utilized a controller gun to initialize each player, thus preventing players from "resurrecting" themselves by re-inserting the yellow weapon key. Each player's data was stored in memory until downloaded by the controller unit at the conclusion of the training exercise. Simulaser made use of hybrid microcircuits to reduce the size of certain components and eliminated the electronic module on the back of the helmet to improve player comfort. Simulaser also manufactured laser detector components and systems for vehicle applications sold to Sandia Labs and EG&G Inc., the operations and maintenance contractor at Kirtland AFB for use in training guards and couriers. Simulaser was acquired by Applied Solar Energy Corp. (ASEC, City of Industry, CA), its major supplier of silicon detectors, in 1984<ref>Lasers & Applications, January 1985</ref>. Later, under contract from Fairchild-Weston Systems, Simulaser produced the laser and detector systems for the AGES/ADII (Air-to-Ground Engagement System/Air Defense II) program for the US Army, outfitting a number of helicopters with training systems and producing laser simulators for the HGSS/GVLLD (Hellfire Ground Support System Simulator/Ground-based Vehicle Laser Locator Designator). [[File:HGSS1.jpg|thumb|Simulaser's HGSS/GVLLD Simlator]] [[File:MITS1.jpg|thumb|Simulaser's MITS unit]] Simulaser also produced the early low rate of production run of MITS (Multiple Independent Target System) and in 1989 won a development contract from the US Army for STOM (Shoot-through Obscuration Miles) that utilized long-wavelength lasers instead of semiconductor lasers in order to penetrate battlefield obscurants<ref>"Battlefield Training in Impaired Visibility", SPIE Vol. 1419, 1991</ref>. Late in 1989, Simulaser was awarded a $35 million production contract for standard MILES gear, subsequently increased to $44 million<ref>Contract DAAA09-89-C-0752, HQ AMCCOM, 30 August 1989</ref>, following which Loral Electro-Optical Systems, Inc., acquired the business of Simulaser from ASEC in October 1989, after which Simulaser ceased to exist.<ref>News release, Applied Solar Energy Corp., October 13, 1989</ref>.
==Later versions== Versions made after 1986 used a loud tone to signal when a soldier was "killed". In order to turn off the noise, the soldier had to remove a yellow key from the laser module on his rifle and insert it into the box on his harness. By removing the key from the laser, the weapon could no longer score hits using the MILES system. With some systems the hit soldier is required to lie on his back to stop the noise and signal others that he is "dead".
MILES 2 was released in 1991–92, and the SAWE (simulated area weapons effects) add-on was first fielded in 1992 using [[Global Positioning System|GPS]] and RF messages so that vehicles and individual soldiers can be killed from a central location due to artillery strikes, or nuclear, biological, and chemical weapons strikes. Implementation in the Summer and Fall of 1992 was at [[Hohenfels, Bavaria|Hohenfels]], Germany at the Combat Maneuver Training Center. In 1993, the range at [[Fort Polk]] was installed and tested. At the time, there were plans to add SAWE at the NTC at [[Fort Irwin Military Reservation|Fort Irwin]], although instead this was implemented by using SAWE-like features via the DCI radio network. This was superseded in aircraft by the implementation of the SMODIM or the [[smart onboard data interface module]] instrumented in 1998 at all three Combat Training Centers (NTC, JRTC, and JMRC).
As of July 2006, the latest version of MILES was MILES XXI, provided by [[Lockheed Martin]].<ref>{{Cite web|publisher=[[Jane's Information Group]]|title=Lockheed Martin Simulation, Training & Support (LM STS) - Multiple Integrated Laser Engagement System (MILES) (United States), Land systems - Tactical engagement simulation |url=http://www.janes.com/articles/Janes-Simulation-and-Training-Systems/Lockheed-Martin-Simulation-Training--Support-LM-STS--Multiple-Integrated-Laser-Engagement-System-MILES-United-States.html |accessdate=2010-07-13}}</ref>
As of 2012 the most current version of fully fielded vehicle platform MILES was the Instrumentable multiple integrated laser engagement system combat vehicle tactical engagement simulation system I-MILES CVTESS). This is provided to the US Army by Saab Defense and Security Training and Simulations. It is manufactured at Saab Training in the company's office in Husqvarna, Sweden. Saab's Main Battle Tank (MBT) Crew Trainer enables the warfighter to perform live precision gunnery and combat training. The MBT Crew Trainer strengthens the entire crew's accuracy and precision. The realism and experience with the tank trainer provides the confidence needed to win the engagement.
I-MILES CVTESS is a laser-based training device to be used on Abrams, Bradley, and opposing forces (OPFOR) tanks and fighting vehicles to provide real-time casualty effects. It is an evolutionary approach for replacing older I-MILES CVTESS equipment currently used in force-on-force training exercises with devices that provide better training fidelity for combat vehicle systems. It reinforces crew duties, reward proper engagement techniques and develop tactical maneuver skills of armor and mechanized infantry combined arms teams up to brigade level. It provides unit commanders an integrated training system in force-on-force and force-on-target training events at homestation training area through instrumented training. The system interfaces with instrumentation systems at maneuver combat training centers (MCTC).
==Users== {{Refimprove section|date=September 2013}} === Private companies === One Shepherd,<ref>{{Cite web|publisher=[[One Shepherd]]|title=One Shepherd|url=http://www.1shepherd.com/|accessdate=2014-02-24}}</ref> a division of TacComp Media, LLC, procured MILES 2000 (Cubic Defense Applications) in early 2007 as a force on force simulation platform for their vocational leadership education program. One Shepherd employs the system to teach leadership through the military decision-making process (MDMP) inherent in tactical patrolling operations and small arms gun fighting. MILES provides immediate feedback to students in a safe-to-fail environment, and affords an experiential exploration of leadership.
* In late 2013 One Shepherd purchased MILES IWS (Universal Systems and Technology Inc.) and now employ both variants in their educational program. * Numerous private training companies have purchased MILES through Homeland Security grant. The terms of the grant significantly restrict the use of MILES by civilian citizens. Nuclear security police contracted under the US Department of Energy represent the largest non-defense market for MILES. * To date, One Shepherd is the only known private institution to make MILES technology available to American citizens.
=== National militaries === {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * Armenia<ref>[https://www.zeltech.com/newsreleases/2014/ZTS-Armenia%20MILES.pdf]</ref> * Australia * Brazil * Bulgaria * Chile * Colombia * Croatia * Czech Republic * Egypt * Estonia * Finland * Georgia<ref>[http://mod.gov.ge/index.php?l=E&m=5&sm=12&ssm=1&acm=1 National Training Centre "Krtsanisi"]. [[Ministry of Defense (Georgia)|Ministry of Defense of Georgia]]. Retrieved 2011-03-01</ref> * Germany (uses own system called ''Ausbildungsgerät Duellsimulator'' (AGDUS)<ref>{{Cite web|title=Press commentary: The Army Battle Simulation Centre (GÜZ): the German Army's main simulation training facility |url= http://www.rheinmetall-defence.com/en/rheinmetall_defence/public_relations/themen_im_fokus/guez/index.php |accessdate=2015-08-08}}</ref> * Hungary * India (uses a System similar to MILES, although not from the same manufacturer) * Ireland * Iran (Uses indigenous designed and manufactured system, similar to MILES){{Citation needed|date=September 2013}} * Israel (for urban warfare training) * Kenya * Latvia * Lithuania * Mexico (uses own system called SAVLE (in Spanish ''Sistema de Adiestramiento Laser Virtual Electromecánico'')<ref>{{Cite web|title=FX-05 SAVLE|url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kbkGwZDsx1s|language=Spanish|accessdate=2010-12-14}}</ref> * Netherlands * Norway (uses a similar system manufactured by [[Saab AB]]) * Poland * Romania * Serbia<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.b92.net/eng/news/politics.php?yyyy=2013&mm=09&dd=13&nav_id=87663|title=U.S. laser system donation presented to military|publisher=B92|date=13 September 2013|accessdate=25 September 2013}}</ref> * Singapore * Slovenia * Slovakia * South Korea * Spain (uses a similar system, Simulador de Combate Individual by Tecnobit)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.onemagazine.es/noticia/14875/industria/el-ejercito-compra-simuladores-de-combate-laser-a-tecnobit-.htmlyyyy=2013&mm=10&dd=19&nav_id=87663|title=El Ejército compra simuladores de combate láser a Tecnobit|publisher=onemagazine|date=19 October 2013|accessdate=1 September 2016}}</ref> * Sweden * Thailand (uses a similar system; the civilian edition of the system has become a game in Thailand)<ref>{{Cite web|title=Mega Force Gun Simulator|url=http://www.megaforce.co.th/en/|access-date=10 April 2018}}</ref> * Turkey * Ukraine (provided by the United States)<ref>[http://www.unian.info/society/1450591-us-supplies-maximum-arms-to-ukraine-media.html U.S. supplies maximum arms to Ukraine: Media], [[UNIAN]] (3 August 2016)</ref> * United States {{div col end}}

(PTI) Developer of MILES Laser Tube Assemblies (Single & Dual types)] * [http://1shepherd.com/ One Shepherd Technical Institute of Leadership, a division of TacComp Media, LLC] * [http://www.peostri.army.mil/PRODUCTS/IMILES_CV_TESS/ PEOSTRI Products, IMILES CVTESS] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20150119045217/http://www.saabgroup.com/Global/Documents%20and%20Images/Land/Training%20and%20Simulation/Live%20Training/CVTESS_web.pdf Saabgroup CVTESS System]

The '''National Center for Appropriate Technology''' (NCAT) is an American organization headquartered in [[Butte, Montana]], that is dedicated to [[appropriate technology]] and [[sustainability]]. Projects specifically deal with [[sustainable energy]], [[sustainable agriculture]] and food, [[sustainable living]], farm energy, and [[climate change]].
It carries out projects within the [[United States]], especially in poor [[rural area]]s. It has regional offices in Davis, California; Fayetteville, Arkansas; San Antonio, Texas; Jackson, Mississippi; and Keene, New Hampshire.<ref>https://www.ncat.org/offices/</ref>
Its headquarters is located in the former [[Silver Bow County Poor Farm Hospital]], which is listed on the U.S. [[National Register of Historic Places]].
==ATTRA== {{Distinguish|Attra}} Since the farm crisis in the 1980s, NCAT has operated ATTRA ([https://attra.ncat.org attra.ncat.org]), the National Sustainable Agriculture Information Service. The program goal is to provide technical assistance to farmers throughout the nation in succeeding with sustainable, organic and regenerative agriculture. The roughly two dozen specialists can assist farmers in everything from pest management and crop selection to farm business planning and marketing. Around 500 publications are available for download on the ATTRA website and the vast majority of them are free. They are based in the latest scientific research and are constantly updated. The website is also home to numerous tutorials, webinars and short videos.
ATTRA was originally an acronym for "Appropriate [[technology transfer|Technology Transfer]] for Rural Areas" which has since fallen out of use and is just "ATTRA".
==See also== * Small Business Technology Transfer programs, which are usually connected with [[Small Business Innovation Research]] programs (for example, the [https://nifa.usda.gov/program/small-business-innovation-research-program-sbir USDA agricultural SBIR])
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == *[https://www.ncat.org/ Official site]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:National Center For Appropriate Technology}} [[Category:Appropriate technology organizations]]
{{International-dev-stub}}

{{Infobox power station | name = PS20 solar power plant | name_official = ''Planta Solar 20'' ([[Spanish language|Spanish]]) | image = PS20andPS10.jpg | image_size = 250px | image_caption = The [[PS10 Solar Power Plant]] in the foreground, with the PS20 in the background. | image_alt = Aerial photographs of the PS10 and PS20 solar power towers. | location_map = Spain | coordinates = {{coord|37|26|38|N|06|15|34|W|type:landmark_region:ES|display=inline,title}} | coordinates_ref = | country = Spain | location = [[Solar Platform]], [[Sanlúcar la Mayor]], [[Seville Province]] | status = Operational | construction_began = 2006 | commissioned = 2009 | decommissioned = | cost = | owner = [[Abengoa Solar]] | operator = | solar_type = CSP | solar_csp_technology = T | solar_concentration = | solar_collectors = 1,255 | solar_collectors_area = | solar_site_area = | solar_site_resource = 2,012 kWh/m<sup>2</sup>/yr | ps_units_manu_model = | ps_electrical_capacity = 20 [[Megawatt|MW]] | ps_electrical_cap_fac = 27% | ps_annual_generation = 48 [[GWh]] | website = | extra = }}
The '''PS20 solar power plant''' ('''PS20''') solar power plant is a [[solar thermal energy]] plant in [[Sanlucar la Mayor]] near [[Seville]] in [[Andalusia]], Spain. It was the world's most powerful solar power tower until the [[Ivanpah Solar Power Facility]] in California became operational in 2014. The 20 [[megawatt]] (MW) [[solar power tower]] produces electricity with large movable mirrors called [[heliostat]]s.<ref name="First EU">{{cite web |url= http://www.ens-newswire.com/ens/mar2007/2007-03-30-02.asp |title= First EU Commercial Concentrating Solar Power Tower Opens in Spain |date= 30 March 2007 |publisher= Environment News Service |accessdate= 20 March 2012 }}</ref><ref>[http://sev.prnewswire.com/oil-energy/20090427/DC0579027042009-1.html Abengoa Solar Begins Operation of World's Largest Solar Power Tower Plant] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090618073353/http://sev.prnewswire.com/oil-energy/20090427/DC0579027042009-1.html |date=2009-06-18 }}</ref>
Construction of PS20 was started in 2006 and it commenced operation in 2009. It features several significant technological improvements over the earlier [[PS10]]. These include a receiver with higher efficiency, various improvements in the control and operational systems, and a better thermal energy storage system.
"PS20 consists of a solar field of 1,255 mirrored heliostats designed by Abengoa Solar. Each heliostat, with a surface area of {{Convert|120|m2|ft2|abbr=on}}, reflects the solar radiation it receives onto the receiver, located on the top of a {{Convert|165|m|ft|adj=mid|-high|0}} tower, producing steam which is converted into electricity by a turbine generator."<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.spanishnews.es/20090428-abengoa-solar-puts-its-ps20-solar-tower-into-operation/id=352/ |title= Abengoa Solar puts its PS20 solar tower into operation |date= 28 April 2009 |work= Spanish News |publisher= |accessdate= 20 March 2012 }}</ref>
"The remaining power plants will be built over the next few years. They will include low- and high-concentration photovoltaic, tower thermoelectric, parabolic-trough collector and Stirling dish plants. Abengoa Solar's parabolic trough plants, [[Solnova Solar Power Station|Solnova]] 1, 3 and 4, which can generate 150 MW of power, are under construction at the [[Solar Platform]]."<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.power-technology.com/projects/Seville-Solar-Tower/ |title= Solar Tower, Seville, Spain |work= Power Technology |publisher= Net Resources International |accessdate= 20 March 2012 }}</ref>
Resulting from cooperation between Ciemat, the IDEA, and the University of Seville, the whole plant is to be completed by 2013, when it will produce approximately 300 MW – energy for around 180,000 homes, equivalent to the needs of the city of Seville. PS20 produces about 48,000 [[megawatt-hour]]s (MW·h) per year, for which it receives €271 (US$360) per MW·h under its [[power purchase agreement]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.nrel.gov/csp/solarpaces/project_detail.cfm/projectID=39 |title= Planta Solar 20 |date= 21 April 2009 |work= Concentrating Solar Power Projects |publisher= [[National Renewable Energy Laboratory]] (NREL), [[United States Department of Energy|U.S. Dept. of Energy]] (DOE) |accessdate= 20 March 2012 }}</ref>
==See also == {{stack|{{Portal|Spain|Sustainable development|Renewable energy}}}} *[[List of solar thermal power stations]] *[[Renewable energy in the European Union]] *[[Solar power in Spain]] *[[Solucar]]

== External links == {{Commons category|PS20 Solar Power Plant}} *{{cite web |url = http://www.abengoasolar.com/corp/web/en/nuestras_plantas/plantas_en_operacion/espana/PS20_la_mayor_torre_comercial_del_mundo.html |title = PS20, the largest solar power tower worldwide |publisher = [[Abengoa Solar]] |accessdate = 20 March 2012 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120621195844/http://www.abengoasolar.com/corp/web/en/nuestras_plantas/plantas_en_operacion/espana/PS20_la_mayor_torre_comercial_del_mundo.html |archivedate = 21 June 2012 |df = }} *[http://www.telvent.com/press/2005/Solucar_media_release_03_august_05.pdf Telvent develops control system for new solar power plants in Seville] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110811230017/http://ec.europa.eu/energy/res/sectors/doc/csp/ps10_final_report.pdf Final technical progress report], for [[European Union]] officials (November 2006) *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/6616651.stm Power station harnesses Sun's rays] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20120210152851/http://www.solarpaces.org/Tasks/Task1/ps10.htm Description and pictures] *[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2007/apr/03/spain.renewableenergy Power tower reflects well on sunny Spain]
